titleStmt.title: Hedy Lamarr: The Most Beautiful Woman in Film

bibl.title: Hedy Lamarr: The Most Beautiful Woman in Film

abstract.p: This biography explores Hedy Lamarr's dual legacy as a Hollywood icon pioneer of spread-spectrum technology, drawing on archival materials and personal correspondence.

div.head: Introduction: Waxworks
div.note: Ruth Barton explains the phenomenon of growing fame of Hedy Lamarr.
div.quote: "Since her death in 2000, and even somewhat before that, Hedy La-marr's reputation has grown. To quite a large extent, this has been because of her increasing fame as an inventor; her design, with the American avant-garde composer George Antheil, for a long-range torpedo-guidance system forms the basis of our modern mobile telephone technology and also played a major part in the Cuban missile crisis. Several retrospectives of her Hollywood films have been staged, both in her hometown of Vienna and on American television. Documentaries have been produced, exploring her career, her personality, and her legacy. She is the subject of numerous Internet sites and entries."
div.note: The author of the book described her interest in Hedy Lamarr's persona in the following way:
div.quote: "My own interest in writing this biography was to explore the consequences of leading a life that was based on an image, and how that life became increasingly fictionalized. I'm interested in how Hedy's image, often literally (in the form of a portrait or painting), threatened to overwhelm her reality and how she fought to hold her own in a system that she both despised and needed."

div.head: A Childhood in Döbling
div.note: This passage reveals how Hedy's childhood was shaped by Vienna's political and social turmoil after WWI. While her Jewish family faced growing antisemitism, her upbringing remained sheltered—a contrast that would later influence her complex relationship with identity and fame.
div.quote: "Hedy was a child of the First World War, an event with sweeping repercussions for the Jews of Vienna. The collapse of the Hapsburg monarchy and the inauguration of the First Republic saw the Viennese Jews, along with the old aristocracy, stripped of their wealth and influence. After the war, fuel shortages and a drastic lowering of living standards left Vienna more susceptible to the city's omnipresent anti-Semitism, and from the 1920s, the Viennese Jews were gradually becoming aware of a new, hostile atmosphere that infiltrated all aspects of society. No doubt the Kieslers felt the shock too, yet life for the young Hedy (pronounced "Hady") was still protected and very traditional."

div.head: The most beautiful girl in the world
div.note: Even as a teenager, Hedy displayed audacity, forging notes and seizing opportunities.
div.quote: "Hedy now signed up for acting classes with Professor Arndt in Vienna.' According to Ecstasy and Me and several interviews that she gave, Hedy forged a handwritten note to the school from her mother and slipped off one day to Austria's largest film studio, Sascha Film Studios, where she talked herself into a job as a script clerk. While there she overheard the assistant director say he would be interviewing actresses the next day to play a secretary. Hedy seized the opportunity: "[…]Going to the assistant director, I said boldly, 'I want to play the part of the secretary?"? According to Ecstasy and Me, her boldness landed her a small part in her first film: Alexis Granowsky's Storm in a Water Glass (Die Blumenfrau von Lin-denau/Sturm im Wasserglas). That assertion, however, was mistaken, as Storm was directed by Georg Jacoby in 1931, and Hedy's first film was actually Jacoby's Gold on the Street (Geld auf der Strasse), which was released by Sascha Film in 1930."

div.head: Ecstasy
div.note: The protests against Ecstasy highlight the duality of Hedy's early fame: criticized for both "too much" and "not enough" eroticism. The Jewish press's interpretation of the backlash hints at the undercurrent of antisemitism she navigated, even as her beauty overshadowed her artistry.
div.quote: "In Frankfurt, screenings of the film were accompanied by protests that took the form of defacing the posters bearing the star's naked image. The protestors were divided into two camps: a Catholic youth organization that was opposed to the film's eroticism, particularly as promoted in its publicity, and filmgoers who were disappointed by its lack of erotic qual-ities.33 Again, the suggestion that the film had been banned in the 1930s because its star was Jewish was revived by the Jewish press. [...] In 1933, however, all this was yet to come and the film's beguiling star was still named Hedy Kiesler and only nineteen years old. She was, as far as most people were concerned, an exquisite Viennese mädl, whose acting abilities were as yet untested by a major dramatic role. Her reputation was the creation of men who were considerably older and worldlier than she. She would soon meet one more such man, her first husband, Fritz Mandl."

div.head: Fritz Mandl
div.note: Hedy's resistance to being "a slave to cinema" reflects her desire for autonomy—ironic given her later Hollywood stardom.
div.quote: "The success and notoriety of Ecstasy opened doors for the young star; although for the moment those were to be stage doors. Interviewed during the shooting of Ecstasy, Hedy was firm: she did not want a Hollywood career. "I don't want to become a slave to cinema," Hedy said. "I want to film when I feel like it, and to take a break when I don't. I'll probably go back to Berlin."' Any mention of a contract with Paramount and a trip to Hollywood with her mother vanished as unexpectedly as they had appeared. What she did not then know was that she had left Berlin and the Weimar film industry for good."
div.note: The opulence of Mandl's world came at a cost: Hedy's freedom. Her shift to conservative dress symbolizes the suppression of her vibrant personality, foreshadowing her eventual escape and reinvention in America.
div.quote: "Once back in Vienna, in early January 1934, Mandl installed his wife in the Mandl mansion, a ten-room apartment at 15 Schwarzenbergplatz near Vienna's famed Ring Boulevard. With marriage came a massive estate that included the renowned Mandl hunting castle, the Villa Fegenberg, near Schwartau. Hedy now had maids, jewels, and wanted for nothing. She had every luxury, she later commented, except freedom.' She began to wear black and to dress more conservatively to rein in her personality. Still she was guaranteed to attract attention wherever she went."

div.head: The most beautiful woman in the world
div.note: No quotes were find in the public domain

div.head: To the Casbah!
div.note: This domestic vignette shows Hedy crafting her own space—literally and metaphorically—in Hollywood. Her hands-on design work mirrors her later inventive spirit, proving her talents extended far beyond the screen.
div.quote: "In September 1938, now feeling assured of a Hollywood career, Hedy bought a house on North Camden Drive in Beverly Hills. With money to spend, she indulged her longtime interest in design. She decorated the house herself and built extra rooms. Then, she added a swimming pool and a pavilion in the garden where guests could change."

div.head: This Dame Is Exotic
div.note: No quotes were find in the public domain

div.head: The Siren of the Picture Show
div.note: Though reduced to a "mannequin", Hedy's visual magnetism eclipsed her limited role—a microcosm of Hollywood's prioritization of her beauty over talent.
div.quote: "Hedy's main function in Ziegfeld Girl is as a mannequin, just as the real-life Dolores of the Follies was. Again Adrian clothed Hedy, this time in costumes that were at once high camp and excessively glamorous. If her narrative contribution was minimal (much less than that of either Judy Garland or Lana Turner), Hedy's visual display was magnificent."

div.head: The Rather Unfeminine Occupation of Inventor
div.note: This passage reveals Hedy's sharp intellect, contrasting starkly with her screen persona. The dismissive coverage of her frequency-hopping invention—now foundational to modern tech—highlights how societal biases obscured her scientific contributions until decades later.
div.quote: "During the war Hedy persuaded the composer and concert pianist George Antheil to work with her on the invention of a radio-controlled torpedo-guidance system, commonly referred to as the "Secret Communication System." This startling fact has only become widely known in recent years; at the time it was reported in the news as a lesser item of interest. Frequency-hopping, the system which has become associated with the actress and the composer, is a fairly straightforward process, although, in the years preceding and during World War Il, its finer points eluded the scientists of the day. The procedure involves sending a series of signals from a transmitter to a receiver in a manner that cannot be inter-cepted, thus allowing for a torpedo (for instance) to be dropped remotely. Not only is it essential that the information pass from transmitter to receiver, it is also crucial that the message cannot be jammed by a third party."

div.head: Enter: Loder
div.note: Hedy was annihilating the "femme fatale" stereotype, revealing a woman intellectually curious and indifferent to her own beauty.
div.quote: "In company, she was happiest discussing politics or just about any other topic and, as Loder acknowledged, she was never ostentatious or out to catch the limelight for herself. Like so many of the people who knew her well, Loder was adamant on another point: "Hedy's best quality was that she was completely unimpressed by her own outstanding beauty. Indeed she seemed oblivious to it." He also adds that, "she never flirted with other men, but then I think she was much more interested in success as a movie star than the opposite sex.""

div.head: Exit: Loder
div.note: No quotes were find in the public domain

div.head: Independence
div.note: Hedy's late-career autonomy ("being the star") clashed with persistent sexism: her sexuality was scrutinized in ways male actors' never were. The backhanded praise of her "competent" performance reflects how critics struggled to reconcile her beauty with artistic merit.
div.quote: "Being frugal, being in control, being the star-Hedy had at last found herself at home in Hollywood. For a brief moment, she was able to exercise her unmistakable abilities and, under Ulmer's direction, she even gave a competent performance (even though a more gifted actor might have guaranteed The Strange Woman the classic status it deserves). As for her predilection for having affairs, this could be dismissed as meddlesome gossip, though it may well be true. There's no denying Hedy was promis-cuous; had she been a man, it would have hardly been worth a mention."

div.head: No Man Leaves Delilah!
div.note: No quotes were find in the public domain

div.head: Acapulco
div.note: Lewis's mockery of Hedy's accent lays bare Hollywood's exoticization of foreign stars. The "disgust" directed at her sexuality reveals the industry's hypocrisy—simultaneously profiting from and punishing her European sensibilities.
div.quote: "'I'm not proud of that film,' Lewis later told Peter Bogdanovich. 'But it proves one thing: that I'm capable of making a stinker.' It also proves how Hedy was still mocked as a foreigner in Hollywood-the comic rendition of her Germanic consonants in Lewis's unpleasant anecdote underlines this. Nor does its tone of disgust suggest a collaborative working relationship-Hedy meant not only foreignness but also an overheated (read foreign) sexuality that both threatened and titillated her director."

div.head: Houston, Texas
div.note: Hedy's dismissive attitude toward TV work ("old-fashioned housewife") reveals her struggle to reconcile her fading stardom with the need to remain relevant.
div.quote: "With her movie career over (even if she didn't know it), Hedy was forced to rely on television to remind casting agents that she still had a professional life. The outcome was less than inspiring and it is surprising that she continued to headline television shows until the late 1960s. It is less surprising that she was deeply ungracious about her new career op-portunity, remarking that "I'm just an old-fashioned housewife who has to do these TV things not to get into a rut." She no longer wished, she said, to continue to appear as a Mata Hari type?"

div.head: A Filthy, Nauseating story
div.note: Her candid admission to DeMille—that courtroom appearances felt more authentic than film roles—exposes the irony of her life: a woman famed for on-screen sensuality found genuine expression in legal battles.
div.quote: "In Ecstasy and Me, Hedy recalls a conversation with Cecil B. DeMille. Asked what her favorite scenes through the years had been, she answered diplomatically that she most preferred the love scene in Samson and Delilah. "Then I told him the truth. I told him I thought several of my appearances in court contributed most to my satisfaction. Everyone acts all the time. I was my most natural and most convincing in court."' It's no wonder that, in later life, her favorite TV show was Judge Judy."
div.note: The publisher's reduction of Hedy's life to "mostly sexual" experiences mirrors how Hollywood commodified her. The courtroom exchange lays bare the double standard: her marriages were framed as scandalous (while male stars' divorces were routine), and her attempt to control her narrative was dismissed as desperation. The phrase "the only thing she had to sell was her sex" crystallizes the industry's lifelong exploitation of her beauty.
div.quote:
Now she was trying to halt the publication of her autobiography. Suing Bar-tholemew House for s9.6 million, she claimed the book was "false, scandalous and vulgar." Isaac Pacht, attorney for the publishers, gave those in the courtroom a taste of what was in the book:
"We are dealing with the experiences, mostly sexual, of a woman out of pictures for fifteen years. She was in the doldrums as far as the picture business is concerned, and she was desperate to revive her name in the public mind. The only thing she had to sell was her sex
"This woman has been married to six men," he continued. "She discarded six of these husbands. But you and I are not interested in that."
"Do you think this is a filthy book?" Judge Nutter enquired of Pacht.
"The language was not very elevating," came the reply, "but sex was the theme of this woman's life."

div.head: Final years
div.note: Hedy's son wanted to return mother to her homeland
div.quote: "Tony Loder promised he would scatter his mother's ashes in the Viennese woods."
div.note: But infortunately he could not...
div.quote: "In the end, Andreas Mailath-Pokorny, City Councillor for the Arts in Vienna, ordained that the city should pay for the memorial. He further announced that a public space in Vienna would be named after Hedy Lamarr and the "Hedy Lamarr Weg" was created. At the time of this writing, however, there is no Ehrengräb bearing the name Hedy Lamarr in Vienna's Zentralfriedhof. Hedy Kiesler is still waiting to come home."
